questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease is brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He has been neglecting symptoms of dizziness and palpitations for the past few days. His ECG is given below. The most possible diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of ventricular fibrillation. 

The features in the above ECG that support the diagnosis are:

  • Disordered electrical ventricular activation with no identifiable QRS complexes
  • No identifiable P-waves, no PR interval

Possible mechanisms of ventricular fibrillation include spiral wave reentry and multiple circulating reentry wavefronts.

The ECG features suggestive of ventricular tachycardia are as follows:

  • Wide QRS complex with abnormal morphology (marked with red arrows in image below)
  • Absence of the P waves
  • Rate >100/min- in the ECG below, it is ~180 beats/min (1500/no. of small boxes between two R waves)

Ventricular tachycardia

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition?
questions.solution:
The ECG of this patient points towards the diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, IV MgSO4 is the treatment of choice. 

IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and prevention of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades de pointes.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

Synchronized cardioversion Defibrillation

Also used in SVT, atrial flutter/fibrillation

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of recurrent palpitation and lightheadedness. An ECG was taken and is shown below. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows the presence of delta waves (preexcitation wave), wide QRS, and short PR interval which are classically seen in WPW syndrome. In this patient, catheter ablation is the best for long-term management. 

Patients with preexcitation who have symptoms of arrhythmia are at risk for developing AF and sudden death if they have an accessory pathway that allows rapid antegrade conduction (preexcitation & tachyarrhythmias are features of WPW syndrome due to the abnormal accessory pathway).

Complications of catheter ablation are rare but include AV block, cardiac tamponade, thromboembolic events, and hematoma at the access site.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of :
questions.solution:
There is depression of the ST segment, a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave, and an increase in the amplitude of U waves which occur at the end of the T wave. These are the findings of hypokalemia.

Hypokalemia can also cause premature atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

Hyperkalemia: causes tall peaked T waves with a shortened QT interval; progressive lengthening of the PR interval and QRS duration; the disappearance of the P wave; and widening of the QRS complex to a sine wave pattern.

Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia causes prolongation of the QT interval. There is a lengthening of the ST segment, while the T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered.

Hypercalcemia: shortening of the QT interval, decrease in the ST segment duration.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department after she complained of palpitations. ECG was taken immediately and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms and ECG findings suggestive of Mobitz type II block.

In the given ECG PR segment remains the same in each successive cycle. Some P waves are not followed by QRS complexes, which means that some of the P waves are blocked. This is typical of Mobitz type II block. 

Heart blocks can be first degree, second degree, and third degree.

  • First-degree AV block occurs due to slowing of conduction through the AV junction. The ECG will show a prolonged PR interval that is more than 200ms.
  • Second-degree heart block occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. Second-degree AV block is subclassified as Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) or Mobitz type II.
    • Mobitz type I block occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. It is characterized by a progressively lengthening PR interval, shortening of the RR interval, and a pause that is less than two times the immediately preceding RR interval.
    • Mobitz type II block occurs in distal or infra-His conduction system and is often associated with intraventricular conduction delays. The PR intervals in this are constant. However, some P waves are not succeeded by the QRS complexes. 
  • Complete heart block occurs when none of the impulses from the atria are conducted to the ventricles. There is no relation between the P waves and QRS complexes.

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His ECG is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical feature and the ECG are pointing towards the diagnosis of Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia.

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate > 100
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Discrete P waves with more than 3 different morphologies (black arrows)
  • Variable PR interval
  • Narrow QRS complex

Multifocal AT (MAT) is characterized by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is the most common arrhythmia seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also seen in hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) (ECG given below)

Rhythm is regular. The rate is 150-200 bpm. P wave may be buried in the QRS complex. PR interval may not be possible to measure. Narrow QRS complex. PSVT can occur in a normal heart. The drug of choice for PSVT is adenosine.

Option B: Atrial fibrillation (ECG given below)

Rhythm is irregularly irregular. Rate is >300 bpm. P wave is absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Atrial flutter (ECG given below)

Rhythm is regular. Rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw tooth shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with no significant past history comes to the emergency department with sudden onset of palpitations. On examination, her pulse is 140 bpm and her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Her ECG is given below. What will be the initial line of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as it shows narrow QRS complexes without visible p waves and pseudo R' waves in aVR lead. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, a carotid sinus massage will be provided as first-line therapy.

Vagal maneuvers like the carotid sinus massage and the Valsalva maneuver are techniques used to increase vagal parasympathetic tone.

Vagal maneuvers transiently increase the arterial pressure in the carotid sinuses and aortic arch. This triggers the baroreceptor reflex, which increases parasympathetic output to the heart via cranial nerve X. 

The right vagus nerve innervates the sinoatrial (SA) node and the left vagus nerve innervates the atrioventricular (AV) node. Stimulation of the right and left vagus nerve cause slowing of the electrical activity within the SA node and AV node.

Thus, vagal stimulation results in a decrease in the speed and frequency of electrical impulses in the heart, which could ultimately slow or terminate a tachydysrhythmia.

Treatment of PSVT:

In hemodynamically unstable patients, QRS-synchronous DC cardioversion should be done.

In hemodynamically stable patients,

  1. Vagal maneuvers such as carotid sinus massage are provided as first-line therapy only if there is a low risk of carotid vascular disease. It is contraindicated in patients with carotid bruit and prior history of stroke.
  2. If the vagal maneuvers fail or cannot be performed, intravenous adenosine can be used.
  3. If adenosine does not work, IV beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem) can be used
  4. Irregular, wide complex tachycardia can be treated with IV procainamide, ibutilide, or cardioversion. 

Care should be taken to perform continuous ECG monitoring with facilities for emergency cardioversion and defibrillation on standby.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with chest pain and dyspnea following an alcohol binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ECG showing narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves is suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia. There is rapid and irregular atrial activation which is transmitted through the atrioventricular node. The conducted ventricular rate is usually rapid and irregularly irregular. It can vary from 110-160 beats/minute. A pulse deficit is an important clinical finding associated with the condition. This arises due to preload reduction. 

Symptoms include palpitations, fatigue, presyncope, and dyspnea. An ECG shows the absence of P waves. 

In acute atrial fibrillation with hemodynamic instability, electrical or chemical cardioversion is the first step. The latter is done by intravenous administration of class III antiarrhythmic - ibutilide. In a stable patient, ventricular rate control is the primary aim. This is done by intravenous or oral administration of beta-blockers. Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil and diltiazem can also be used. 

If the current episode duration is >48 hours, cardioversion can precipitate thromboembolic complications. In such cases, cardioversion should be carried out only after 3 weeks of anticoagulation. It has to be continued for 4 weeks after cardioversion. Another option is to evaluate the presence of a thrombus in the left atrial appendage. This can be done either by transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) or high-resolution CT.

If the duration is <48 hours and there are no high-risk factors, cardioversion can be done. The CHA2DS2-VASc scoring system is used to assess stroke risk. 

Warfarin is recommended in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves who present with atrial fibrillation. In mitral stenosis, thrombi arise frequently from the dilated left atrium. Atrial fibrillation in the absence of mitral stenosis is known as nonvalvular atrial fibrillation. Oral factor Xa inhibitors such as apixaban, edoxaban, or rivaroxaban can be used in such cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease comes to the clinic with complaints of dyspnea. Interpret the ECG finding.
questions.solution:
The P waves in the given ECG are broad and notched. This is the P mitrale pattern which is seen in left atrial enlargement.

This patient has likely developed mitral stenosis (heard as a mid-diastolic murmur) secondary to his rheumatic heart disease. Mitral valve stenosis and atrial inflammation in rheumatic carditis lead to left atrial dilation. 

The features of P mitrale are:

  • lead II: broad (>2.5mm) notched P waves
  • Lead V1: Biphasic wave with a prominent negative terminal component (representing delayed depolarization of the LA)

P pulmonale is seen in right atrial enlargement. 

Option A: The rabbit ear pattern is seen in the right bundle branch block. The ECG of RBBB below shows the rSR' pattern of the QRS complex (rabbit ear) in leads V1-V2 and slurred S wave in lead V6.

Option D: Sawtooth pattern in ECG is seen in atrial flutter (shown below).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:

  • Wide QRS complex- QRS ≥120 ms 
  • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
  • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) 

MI can have the following ECG changes:

  • ST-segment elevation- zone of injury
  • T wave depression
  • Deep Q waves- late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)

questions.text: A patient's ECG strip is given below. His cardiac output was found to be 4.8 L/min. What is the stroke volume?
questions.solution:
Cardiac output is calculated by the following formula -

Cardiac output = Heart rate x Stroke volume

The patient's cardiac output is 4.8L/min.

His heart rate can be calculated from the rhythm strip given i.e., HR = 300/number of large squares between consecutive beats. There are approximately 5 large boxes between beats in this ECG.

HR = 300/5 = 60 beats/min.

Therefore, the patient's stroke volume = CO/HR = 4.8L/min/60 beats/min = 0.08 L = 80ml

questions.text: Which of the following leads would show maximum R wave with the cardiac axis as +90 degrees?
questions.solution:
The lead aVF would show maximum R wave with the cardiac axis as +90 degrees.

The cardiac axis represents the mean QRS axis. The normal adult QRS axis is between -30 degrees and +100 degrees, which is directed downward and to the left (considering the mean to be around +70 degrees).

The axis of lead aVF is +90 degrees. If the cardiac axis is +90 degrees, it would be in the same direction as lead aVF and hence aVF would show maximum R wave amplitude.

questions.text: In Einthoven’s triangle, what is the value of lead III when lead I = 1mV and lead II = 2mV ?
questions.solution:
According to Einthoven's law, 

Lead I + Lead III=Lead II.

Lead III = Lead II – Lead I = (2-1) =1 mV.

questions.text: In a normal ECG obtained from a patient, a biphasic P wave may be seen in which of the following lead(s)?
questions.solution:
In a normal ECG, a biphasic P wave is seen in lead V1 only.

Lead V1 is a chest lead. So, it records potentials in the horizontal plane. The P wave in lead V1 consists of:

  • Positive component reflecting right atrial depolarization (due to anteriorly oriented vector)
  • Negative component reflecting left atrial depolarization (due to posteriorly oriented vector)

questions.text: ECG of a patient who was brought to the casualty due to severe chest pain followed by syncope is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of atrial flutter.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes, hence it is supraventricular tachycardia. The RR intervals are regular and the normal P waves are replaced by sawtooth-shaped waves, known as flutter waves.

In atrial flutter, the ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio. The commonest AV ratio is 2:1. In the above ECG, the rhythm is atrial flutter 4:1 block with an atrial rate of about 270 and a ventricular rate of 68/min.

The image below shows sawtooth shaped waves in atrial flutter.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency following an episode of syncope during his morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 5 yrs back. His present ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for the patient?
questions.solution: The ECG shows wide QRS complex tachycardia with no p waves suggesting the diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia (VT). Clinical features of exercise intolerance and the presence of ischemic heart disease also support the diagnosis of VT. Since he is hemodynamically unstable, the next best step is DC cardioversion. For stable patients, amiodarone is given intravenously.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man who is a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension experiences severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and profuse sweating. He was admitted to the emergency ward. An ECG is taken which is as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding blood lactate dehydrogenase levels in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden onset chest pain with profuse sweating and 12 Lead Electrocardiogram (ECG) with ST-segment elevation in Leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of myocardial Infarction. Serum LDH 1 > LDH 2 levels are seen in this condition. 

Under normal conditions, LDH 2 is predominantly present in the blood and LDH 1 is predominantly present in the heart. So, normally LDH 2 > LDH 1 in blood. When cardiac tissue is damaged LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream. This results in a flipped lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) ratio where LDH 1 > LDH 2.

LDH is a tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (heart) and M isoform (muscle)

questions.text: A patient with a history of DVT currently presents with tachypnea and tachycardia. Chest X-ray shows focal oligemia. The ECG is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of pulmonary embolism. ECG shows the S1Q3T3 sign (i.e, an S wave in lead I, a Q wave in lead III, and an inverted T wave in lead III) that is relatively specific but insensitive. The most common sign of pulmonary embolism is tachypnea.

Most common symptom of pulmonary embolism is dyspnea. Most common ECG abnormality in pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia.Most common preliminary investigation used is D-dimer.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of this patient based on the given ECG?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, there is a large S-wave in lead I and a very large R-wave in V1. This is suggestive of right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH).

Diagnostic criteria for RVH:

  • Dominant R wave in V1 (R/S ratio > 1).
  • Dominant S wave in V5 or V6 (R/S ratio < 1).
  • Right ventricular strain pattern - ST depression/T wave inversion in the right precordial (V1-4) and inferior leads (II, III, aVF)
  • Right axis deviation of +110° or more.

For left ventricular hypertrophy, Sokolow Lyon criteria is commonly used.

It is based on the presence of tall left precordial R waves and deep right precordial S waves (S wave in V1 + [R wave in V5 or V6] >35 mm).

questions.text: A male patient who is suffering from a psychotic disorder is on antipsychotic, antidepressant and antihypertensive treatment. He suddenly developed tachycardia and chest tightness. On evaluation he had metabolic acidosis. ECG showed widened QRS complex and prolonged QT interval. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of torsades de pointes. Only amitriptyline causes this condition, among the above drugs.

Torsades de pointes (French: twisting of points) is a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline on ECG.

questions.text: In ECG tracings,  sharp irregular spikes of the baseline that are particularly prominent in the limb leads are typically seen in

choices.text: Recording done with paper speed of 12.5 mm/s
Recording done with paper speed of 50 mm/s

questions.solution:
Sharp irregular spikes of the baseline that are particularly prominent in the limb leads are seen in a patient that is not relaxed. 

Though the ECG recorders are configured to pick up the electrical frequency generated by the heart better, they also detect the contractions of skeletal muscles. So, unless the patient is relaxed and lying down comfortably, the tracing may show some skeletal muscle activity.

Ex:- 

A patient that is shivering due to cold, or one that has involuntary movements due to conditions like Parkinson's, etc would cause spikes in the baseline of the ECG.

In the case of shivering, the spikes would be more exaggerated and synchronized than that seen in a patient that is not adequately relaxed, because of the skeletal muscle groups contracting together in case of shivering.

Other options:

  • Patients with hypothyroidism would show bradycardia, low voltage QRS complexes, and widespread T-wave inversions.
  • The recording is normally done with a paper speed of 25 mm/s.
    • Recording at 12.5 mm/s, which is slower than normal, would cause QRS complex that are close together (creating the false impression of a rapid heart rate) and P waves, QRS complexes, and T waves that are narrow and spiky
    • Recording at 50 mm/s, which is faster than normal, would produce longer intervals between QRS complexes (creating the false impression of a slow heart rate), widened QRS complexes, and an apparently long QT interval.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female patient with end-stage kidney disease comes for a follow-up. An ECG is done which is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows tall, peaked T waves and loss of P waves. These findings and the clinical scenario suggest the likely diagnosis of hyperkalemia.

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level of more than 5.5 mEq/L. 

Hyperkalemia is a dangerous electrolyte abnormality that can cause drastic conduction changes. It can be diagnosed by a sequence of changes affecting the ST-T segments and QRS complex. ST-T segment changes reflect a change in repolarization while QRS complex changes reflect a change in depolarization.

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

S. No. Serum potassium level ECG change
1 5.5 - 6.5 mEq/L tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
2 6.5 - 7.5 mEq/L loss of P waves
3 7.0 - 8.0 mEq/L widened QRS complex
4 > 8.0 mEq/L sine wave

 

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, potassium-sparing diuretics. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. Insulin reduces the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. Dextrose counteracts the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.text: Which lead does the given ECG tracing represent in a normal ECG?
questions.solution:
As all the waves (P, QRS, T) are negative in the given ECG, it should be lead aVR. All the depolarisations waves (P, QRS, T) move away from lead aVR in the normal sinus.

Depolarisation wave moving towards the positive pole of the lead (or active electrode) produces a positive deflection in the ECG and depolarization moving away from the positive pole of the lead produces a negative deflection in the ECG.

The lead aVR provides information from the right upper side of the heart.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease presents with palpitations for the last 3 days. A transesophageal echo shows a thrombus in the left atrium. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following should be done to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is in atrial fibrillation and it should be treated by initiating anticoagulation. 

The patient's ECG shows irregular atrial activation and an irregular ventricular rate which is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. In addition, his CHA2DS2-VASc score is 2 (history of ischemic heart disease and age of 70). These factors along with the presence of a left atrial thrombus require initiating anticoagulation.  

Electrical cardioversion is contraindicated in this patient due to his risk of stroke and the presence of an atrial thrombus.

The treatment of atrial fibrillation depends on three things: duration of symptoms, the severity of symptoms, and the risk of stroke.

The duration of atrial fibrillation - those who present within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms have a lower risk of an existing atrial thrombus and can be safely cardioverted. Those who present with unknown or known onset of more than 48 hours should ideally be anticoagulated before cardioversion. This patient has had symptoms of atrial fibrillation for at least three days. 

The severity of atrial fibrillation refers to the presence of other symptoms and signs. These could include hypotension, pulmonary edema, or angina and are reflective of the cardiac health prior to the onset of fibrillation. This patient is otherwise stable and has no other symptoms and signs of atrial fibrillation. Patients who are unstable and have developed acute onset atrial fibrillation should be reverted to normal sinus rhythm when possible. 

The risk of stroke in a patient can be calculated using the CHA2DS2-VASc score. 

Risk factors Points
Congestive heart failure 1
Hypertension 1
Age > 75 years 2
Diabetes mellitus 1
Stroke/TIA/Embolus 2
Vascular disease 1
Age 65 - 75 years 1
Sex category - female 1

Anticoagulation should be considered in those with a score of 1 and should be administered in those with a score of 2 or more. 

A combination of those three factors should be considered to determine the next best step in treatment.

Patients with onset within < 48 hours and a low risk of stroke can be cardioverted immediately. This can be done by administering a QRS synchronous shock of 200J. 

A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) can be performed at the time of presentation to look for an atrial thrombus. If none is present, then the patient can be cardioverted followed by a minimum of four weeks of anticoagulation. 

In patients with the onset of atrial fibrillation of more than 48 hours and a higher risk of stroke due to pre-existing conditions should receive anticoagulation before cardioversion. They can be anticoagulated for 3 weeks before cardioversion, followed by further 4 weeks of anticoagulation.

questions.text: A patient with dizziness and breathing difficulty came to the emergency department. The ECG is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia. This along with the patient's symptoms suggests a likely diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

Electrical alternans is the beat-to-beat alternation in the ECG waveform. In cardiac tamponade, this is caused by the periodic swinging motion of the heart in a large pericardial effusion.

questions.text: A male patient aged 72 years comes to the emergency room with a feeling of impending doom and palpitations. The emergency physician orders an ECG. What is your diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.solution: The given ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4 which is suggestive of acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction (MI). ST depression in the leads III and aVF signifies an old inferior wall infarction.

questions.text: A man, aged 67 years, with a history of COPD now complains of swelling in both feet for 6 months and dyspnoea on exertion and dry cough for 1 week. An ECG was done and the lead II showed this pattern. Which of the following options is responsible for this ECG finding?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, a peaked P wave can be seen. This is called "P pulmonale".  The patient is showing features of right heart failure and right atrial overload is responsible for the above ECG finding.

The features of P pulmonale include:

  • Amplitude of the P wave is >2.5mm on Lead II.
  • Prominent positive wave in the biphasic P wave of lead V1.

questions.text: Identify the ECG feature of ventricular tachycardia seen in the given image.
questions.solution:
The ECG feature of ventricular tachycardia seen in the given image is a fusion beat. It occurs when a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex.

Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is defined as ≥ 3 consecutive premature ventricular contractions at a rate of >100/min.

  • Fusion beats- occur when a sinus and ventricular beat coincides to produce a hybrid complex
  • Capture beats occur when the SA node transiently ‘captures’ the ventricles, that is, ventricles are depolarized by the impulses from the SA node producing a QRS complex of normal duration.

Polymorphic QRS, that is, continuously changing QRS morphology is seen in Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Triphasic QRS (eg. RSR′ pattern on V1) is seen in supraventricular tachycardias with the wide QRS complex.
